name: Fundamentals of Derivatives
description: Understanding differentiation as a mathematical tool to measure rate of change.

cards.title: Limits & Continuity
cards.description: Exploring the foundational concept of limits and ensuring function continuity before differentiation.
bulletpoints: Define a limit using epsilon-delta notation: \[ \lim_{x \to a} f(x) = L \iff \forall \epsilon > 0, \exists \delta > 0, \text{ such that } |x - a| < \delta \Rightarrow |f(x) - L| < \epsilon \].
Evaluate limits using direct substitution, factoring, and L'Hôpital’s Rule: \[ \lim_{x \to 0} \frac{\sin x}{x} = 1 \].
Identify continuous and discontinuous functions by checking if: \[ \lim_{x \to a} f(x) = f(a) \].

cards.title: Basic Derivative Rules
cards.description: Learning fundamental differentiation rules to compute rates of change.
bulletpoints: Power Rule: \[ \frac{d}{dx} x^n = n x^{n-1} \].
Product Rule: \[ \frac{d}{dx} [uv] = u' v + u v' \].
Quotient Rule: \[ \frac{d}{dx} \left( \frac{u}{v} \right) = \frac{u' v - u v'}{v^2} \].
Chain Rule: \[ \frac{d}{dx} f(g(x)) = f'(g(x)) g'(x) \].
Differentiate exponential and trigonometric functions: \[ \frac{d}{dx} e^x = e^x, \quad \frac{d}{dx} \sin x = \cos x \].

cards.title: Higher-Order Derivatives & Concavity
cards.description: Examining the second and third derivatives for curvature and physical interpretation.
bulletpoints: Second derivative: \[ f''(x) = \frac{d^2 f}{dx^2} \] represents concavity.
Test for inflection points by solving \( f''(x) = 0 \).
Applications to acceleration: \[ a(t) = v'(t) = x''(t) \].

cards.title: Implicit Differentiation
cards.description: Differentiating equations where \( y \) is defined implicitly.
bulletpoints: Differentiate both sides of an equation: \[ \frac{d}{dx} [x^2 + y^2] = \frac{d}{dx} [25] \].
Apply the Chain Rule to \( y \): \[ 2x + 2y \frac{dy}{dx} = 0 \].
Solve for \( \frac{dy}{dx} \) to find slopes in implicit curves.

cards.title: Applications of Derivatives
cards.description: Using derivatives for real-world optimization, curve sketching, and motion analysis.
bulletpoints: Find critical points by solving \( f'(x) = 0 \).
Classify extrema using the First Derivative Test.
Use Related Rates: \[ \frac{dx}{dt} \] and \[ \frac{dy}{dt} \] to model changing systems.
Apply derivatives to motion equations: \[ v(t) = x'(t), \quad a(t) = v'(t) \].

cards.title: Partial Derivatives & Multivariable Functions
cards.description: Extending differentiation to functions of multiple variables.
bulletpoints: Compute \( \frac{\partial f}{\partial x} \) while treating \( y \) as a constant.
Use the Gradient \( \nabla f = \left( \frac{\partial f}{\partial x}, \frac{\partial f}{\partial y} \right) \).
Apply to **electric field intensity**: \[ \mathbf{E} = -\nabla V \].

cards.title: Bioelectric Derivatives & Energy Flow
cards.description: Applying derivatives to bioelectric psionic energy dynamics.
bulletpoints: Model bioelectric charge distribution using Maxwell’s Equations.
Calculate energy flow using the Poynting vector: \[ \mathbf{S} = \mathbf{E} \times \mathbf{H} \].
Differentiate neural action potential waveforms: \[ \frac{dV}{dt} = \frac{-V}{RC} \].

cards.title: Laplacian & Wave Equations in Energy Fields
cards.description: Differential equations governing energy waves and bioelectric fields.
bulletpoints: Solve the Laplace Equation: \[ \nabla^2 V = 0 \].
Apply the Wave Equation: \[ \frac{\partial^2 \psi}{\partial t^2} = c^2 \nabla^2 \psi \].
Interpret solutions in the context of psionic resonance fields.

cards.title: Fourier Derivatives & Frequency Analysis
cards.description: Using derivatives to analyze signal components in psionic energy fields.
bulletpoints: Fourier Transform Derivative Rule: \[ \mathcal{F}\{ f'(x) \} = i \omega F(\omega) \].
Use frequency components to **analyze energy modulation patterns**.
Apply spectral analysis to **brainwave activity and psionic harmonics**.

cards.title: Lagrangian & Variational Derivatives
cards.description: Applying calculus of variations to psionic energy systems.
bulletpoints: Lagrangian mechanics: \[ L = T - V \].
Euler-Lagrange equation: \[ \frac{d}{dt} \left( \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}} \right) - \frac{\partial L}{\partial q} = 0 \].
Optimize psionic energy paths using extremal functionals.
